text: you
also so talk a little bit about your
your sort of personal motivations to
tell these stories and and you know the
process of I guess finding the heart
that heart that's if it's that's inside
all these stories and concepts for me
basically I think what I wanted to do is
have a book for kids so that they
experience like a fun experience with
science as early as possible because as
soon as they go to school it's kind of a
bit of a crapshoot depending on what
teacher you get what school you go to
science can be taught really really well
but it's not taught really well across
the board and who I really wanted to do
is have this really visually appealing
book which kids would love I remember
reading books like science books as a
kid and then like my mind being blown at
some of the stuff they were talking
about and then the other thing is as
well like one sad thing I find when I
speak to adults about science is that
you know I say I'm a physicist and then
they're like oh I was rubbish at physics
in school and somehow they've left
school thinking that you know they
didn't get a good grade and so now
they're bad at science and I think
that's really sad as well because I
think is as you grow up your brain
develops you obviously you learn more
stuff and so it's so sad that adults put
themselves in that category of never you
know being engaged with science anymore
so I'm hoping as well like the parents
who are reading their kids this book
might also be like alright that wow
that's I didn't realize that and maybe
they can kind of get some of that as
well so yeah yeah I get it getting to
the school thing and I don't know if
this is unique to me but I don't think
it is very few people I've ever met have
been inspired by a textbook right
they're inspired by the popular science
article they read in National Geographic
or I was talking to Jennifer earlier and
it was the elegant universe I'm a member
of the Planetary Society right so
anybody else a Planetary Society person
yeah
so Bill Nye the Science Guy is now Bill
Nye the planetary guy and he talks about
the passion beauty and joy of
exploration in science and very rarely
do you get passion beauty or joy it's
like none of the above in your typical
textbook but in the stories you're
you're allowed and in fact you're
expected to project those things and get
people excited the textbooks are there
waiting if you want to start to learn
the math and if you want to start to
practice and be a practicing scientist
having these books being a jumping on
point for science is I guess one of my
goals and one of the things that I think
you can do with this sort of thing
